Award.AwardTitle: TUES: The Development and Assessment of a New Test and Product Engineering Certificate Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology is partnering with local industry in developing a certificate program in Test and Product Engineering. Test and product engineers are needed in the semiconductor industry to ensure that small manufacturing defects do not impact the performance of integrated-circuit chips. Staggering improvements in the semiconductor industry have resulted in devices with incredible performance at the cost of increasing test difficulty. The learning curve for test and product engineers is long and slow, and few universities provide students with background in this area.

To address this industrial need, this project is developing two Test and Product Engineering courses with an intense hands-on laboratory component to support a certificate program in Test and Product Engineering. Strong industrial input is ensuring that the courses and laboratories are relevant to industry needs. Educational research expertise is ensuring that the courses and laboratories are improving students' higher-order thinking skills, creativity and problem-solving abilities. The project is applying a novel, industry-centered assessment strategy to determine whether the courses meet their goal of reducing the time it takes for students to be productive in the integrated-circuit industry. Materials are being developed to allow other universities to adopt these courses even if they do not have the expensive lab equipment necessary to perform the hands-on labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quickly and efficiently testing integrated-circuits for manufacturing defects effecting performance is a critical part of the integrated circuit industry. However, there are few universities teaching this essential field leaving companies in desperate need of students with the appropriate skill set. With the support of NSF, we have joined with industry to develop a series of courses and certificate of concentration in the area of test and product engineering.

One key outcome of the work performed in this grant is the development of course materials that encourage intellectual development and improve critical thinking skills. By repeatedly exposing the students to different levels of open-ended problem-solving experiences on homework assignments, lab exercises, exams, and projects, students built their confidence and ability to handle this higher level of thinking. Students in multiple classes showed statistically significant improvements in their critical thinking skills, measured by a nationally accepted critical-thinking assessment test. Critical thinking skills most impacted by these courses were (i) identifying alternative interpretations for data or observations, (ii) integrating information to solve real-world problems, and (iii) learning and applying new information to solve real-world problems. Students corroborated these results by self-reporting their own improvements on the same critical-thinking skills as a result of their experiences in these courses.

Another key outcome of this work is the production of more students interested and capable of performing well in the integrated-circuit industry, impacting the industrial need for employees in these areas. As a result of the courses and the certificate program developed under this grant, Rose-Hulman saw the percentage of electrical and computer engineering students that joined integrated-circuit companies upon graduation triple.  This result suggests both increased student interest in the integrated-circuit area as well as increased company interest in hiring Rose-Hulman students. An alumni survey asked students who took one or more of the testing courses how they felt their abilities compared to other students entering the job market at the same time. 88% of the alumni felt that they required less time to be productive compared to their peers. 88% felt they had more skill in the testing area than their peers, and 84% felt that they had more confidence in testing than their peers. The work in this grant has had an impact on the industrial need for students with test and product engineering experience.

In order to have a higher impact on the semiconductor industry and higher-education, the work performed in this grant has been disseminated to the academic community. The courses developed in this grant have been described in detail in three conference papers, the types of exercises that encourage intellectual development has been presented in a journal paper (in review), and the materials used in the courses have been placed on a website for other universities to learn from or use. It is the hope of the PIs that other universities can learn from their experiences and re-create the same intellectual development in other students elsewhere and encourage more students to go into the integrated-circuit industry with a knowledge of testing and product engineering.
